question: What statistics and sources demonstrate the scale and growth of drone warfare by both Russia and Ukraine in the conflict from 2022–2024?
question_context: This addresses the foundational need to cite quantitative evidence of proliferation and helps establish the premise for the thesis regarding a paradigmatic shift.
answer:
Russia began the 2022 invasion with an estimated pre-war UAV fleet of approximately 2,000 drones, while Ukraine had considerably fewer; however, by 2023-2024, both countries massively scaled up drone usage and production to unprecedented levels. Current figures indicate Russia has utilized up to 1.4 million aerial drones, while Ukraine has deployed about 1.5 million UAVs in total since the conflict began, signifying escalation to the scale of millions of drones used regularly in the fighting[1][2]. Russia’s drone manufacturing capacity has notably increased, with the Kremlin reportedly producing more than 6,000 Shahed-type strike drones monthly after initially purchasing them from Iran[2]. This factory in Alabuga, Tatarstan, dramatically reduced the cost of these drones from around $200,000 per unit in 2022 to approximately $70,000 by 2025, with some estimates placing costs as low as $20,000-$50,000 per drone[2]. Russia’s nightly barrages have grown accordingly, with records showing it launched a total of 6,443 drones and missiles into Ukraine in July 2025, marking the highest monthly total of the war and averaging around 201 drone attacks daily[3]. Ukraine has correspondingly ramped up its drone production, manufacturing roughly 800,000 drones in 2023 and 2 million in 2024, with projections of up to 5 million additional UAVs expected within 2025[1][4].

The conflict’s drone warfare is characterized not only by sheer volume but also by tactical innovation. Ukraine has adopted a decentralized, volunteer-driven, networked drone production and deployment approach, leveraging hundreds of companies and grassroots initiatives to supply as much as 90% of its battlefield UAVs[5]. In contrast, Russia has adopted a more centralized, technologically evolving model, integrating AI capabilities such as terminal guidance, target-lock, and image recognition into its drones, alongside large-scale production and recent innovations such as fiber optic-controlled drones that evade conventional electronic warfare methods[1][6]. Both nations have been driven by military necessity to compensate for limited air force capabilities, using drones extensively for surveillance, targeted strikes, and electronic warfare[2][5].

These figures and developments illustrate a paradigmatic shift in military aviation and warfare. The use of drones has escalated to replace traditional artillery in many scenarios—where artillery shells are scarce, drones serve as consumable munitions with tactical benefit, deployed by the hundreds of thousands and becoming integral to daily combat operations[1][7]. Consequently, drone warfare in this conflict exemplifies a transformation in battlefield dynamics, pushing both Russia and Ukraine to pursue rapid innovation and production expansion, making the 2022–2024 Russia-Ukraine conflict a defining case of large-scale unmanned aerial warfare in modern warfare history[2][5][7].

Updated Sep 2, 2025, 12:53 PM ET
PUBLISHED Aug 22, 2025, 12:01 AM ET
As Russia’s war machine grinds forward in eastern Ukraine, there is another offensive being waged far beyond the front line. Russia is ramping up nightly drone attacks on Ukrainian cities and civilian infrastructure, and as it rapidly increases its production of those weapons its strikes are intensifying. 
Many of the drones aren’t particularly fast or high-tech, but they are cheap enough for the Kremlin to launch more than 700 in one night, in an effort to overwhelm Ukraine’s air defenses and decimate civilian morale, experts say. 
After obtaining Iranian designs for Shahed attack drones, Russia [built its own massive factory](https://www.cnn.com/2025/08/08/europe/russia-drone-factory-iran-intl) to churn out thousands of these weapons each month. Its evolving tactics are forcing Ukraine to fight back with more expensive ammunition and innovations, as less costly methods of defense become less effective. 
The rapid increase in drone strikes shows how warfare has evolved to rely on these unmanned autonomous vehicles. 
Ukraine and Russia have been driven to improve drone capabilities to compensate for deficiencies in air force capabilities, a dynamic that isn’t applicable to all Western powers. But experts say that the United States and its European NATO allies are actively working to improve drones and counter-drone operations to retain an advantage in any future conflicts. 
“NATO will probably end up using drones on a large scale. Not at the same scale as Russia and Ukraine, because we’ve got these massive air forces that we’ve invested in and that can strike with a lot of power very quickly – but as a complement to that,” Robert Tollast, a research fellow focused on land warfare at the Royal United Services Institute (RUSI), told CNN.

Taiwan is already looking into developing large numbers of cheap attack drones, Tollast said. Non-state actors across the globe and drug cartels are also increasingly relying on drones. “These are going to pose a huge challenge to unprepared armies around the world,” he added. 
This is how Russia’s drone campaign operates – and how Ukraine is working to fight back. 
Russia is moving toward producing more than 6,000 Shahed-type drones each month, Ukraine’s Defense Intelligence told CNN. And it’s much cheaper to produce the attack drones inside Russia compared to earlier in the war, when Moscow was purchasing them from Tehran. 
“In 2022, Russia paid an average of $200,000 for one such drone,” a Ukrainian Defense Intelligence source said. “In 2025, that number came down to approximately $70,000,” due to the large-scale production at the Alabuga drone factory in Russia’s Tatarstan region. 
But cost estimates vary greatly – the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), a DC-based think tank, found that estimates for Shahed-136s ranged from $20,000 to $50,000 per drone. By comparison, a single surface-to-air missile interceptor can cost more than $3 million. 
That relatively low cost makes it possible for the Kremlin to ramp up its nightly drone attacks, as well as conduct more frequent large-scale attacks. Earlier in the war, major missile-and-drone salvos happened roughly once a month. By mid-2025, they occured every eight days on average, according to by CSIS. 
To many civilians, the constant threat of drone attacks is terrifying.

# Russia launches 6,400 drones, missiles into Ukraine in record-breaking month
The scale of Russia's nightly strikes has been steadily increasing.
August 1, 2025, 1:07 AM
More than three years into Russia's full-scale invasion, Ukrainians across the country retreat each night to bomb shelters and metro stations in a nightly ritual necessitated by the long reach of Moscow's drones and missiles. This summer, Ukrainians are spending more time in such shelters than ever before.
The first bombardments of Kyiv and other major cities began in the early morning of Feb. 24, 2022, as Russian troops surged across Ukraine's borders on several axes. In the years since, the attacks have never stopped.
Through July, Russia launched a record 6,443 drones and missiles into the country, according to data published by the Ukrainian air force. The total is the highest of the war to date, and around 13% more than were recorded in June.
The scale and complexity of Russia's drone and missile barrages have steadily increased through the war. The Iranian-designed Shahed strike drone -- adopted enthusiastically by the Russian military and rebranded as the Geran -- has become the workhorse of Moscow's nightly harassment of Ukrainian cities and vital infrastructure.
For many Ukrainians, the "flying mopeds," as the Shahed and Geran variants have become known due to their distinctive sound, are emblematic of the Russian threat.
The strikes are terrorizing and deadly. June saw the highest monthly level of Ukrainian civilian casualties in more than three years, according to data published by the UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission in Ukraine -- 232 people killed and 1,343 people injured.
An explosion of a Russian drone is seen in Kyiv, Ukraine, on July 21, 2025.

Neither Russia nor Ukraine publish data detailing the scale of their own strike campaigns. Ukraine's air force publishes a daily tally of Russian drone and missile strikes, while Russia's Defense Ministry only publishes figures of Ukrainian drones shot down.
July marked a high-water mark for Russian drone attacks on Ukraine. Data published by the Ukrainian air force and analyzed by ABC News recorded a total of 6,245 attack and decoy drones launched into the country over the past month at an average rate of around 201 per day.
Russia also launched 198 missiles, with an average of more than six each day.
Though Ukraine's interception rate is significant, plenty of projectiles arrive with devastating effect. July saw around 89% of drones and around 61% of missiles shot down or otherwise suppressed.
By comparison, June saw 5,438 drones and 239 missiles fired into Ukraine, with a daily average of 181 drones and nearly eight missiles. The air force downed or suppressed 87.2% of all drones and 73% of missiles during June.
And in May, Russia launched a total of 3,835 drones and 117 missiles, for an average of around 124 drones and nearly four missiles each day. Across the month, 85.7% of drones and 57% of missiles were shot down or suppressed.
"Right now, Ukraine sees around 300 to 400 drones attacking civilian targets every day -- these types of numbers were unheard of in 2023 or 2024," Yuriy Boyechko, the founder and CEO of the Hope for Ukraine charity, told ABC News.
Moscow shows no sign of letting up. Russian officials and media have made much of the country's growing drone production capabilities. A recent report by the Zvezda television channel, for example, showed operations at a Geran factory in Alabuga in Russia's Republic of Tatarstan, with workers constructing and piling up dozens of attack drones ready for delivery.

## JUST IN: Russia Expands Drone Capabilities as Ukraine Conflict Continues (UPDATED)
While many of Ukraine’s technological advancements resulting from the war with Russia are well-known, Russian capabilities are also continuing to evolve, including the integration of artificial intelligence into drones, experts said May 28.
The war has been laden with drone-related innovations since its beginning, with each innovation giving rise to a counter-innovation on the opposing side, experts said during a panel discussion hosted by the Center for Strategic and International Studies.
“Just like Ukraine, [the] Russian military is working on [the] development of artificial intelligence and integration of certain forms of AI in their drones,” said Samuel Bendett, senior associate at the center’s Europe, Russia and Eurasia program.
Bendett said Russia is currently using AI for terminal guidance, target lock and image recognition. A drone operator is still needed to direct the system and approve the target, while the AI is used to correctly lock and fly to the human-designated target, he explained.
Like Ukraine, Russia is also working toward improved battlefield data collection and analysis and is developing AI to aid in decision-making and data gathering, he said. 
“Russians are calling for the greater integration of different types of robotic systems from multiple domains in a single sort of unified information battlefield space,” Bendett said. “Whether that’s going to happen soon is an open question.”
Russia’s military has long placed a “massive emphasis” on AI research and development to incorporate greater autonomy for data analysis, decision-making and faster action, Bendett said. He described a recent “groundswell of volunteer and startup activities who have access to commercial technologies,” enabling each to incorporate AI into their products.

“I think if this conflict were to continue, or if we’re looking at how [the] Russian military is going to be influenced by what happened in Ukraine, I think artificial intelligence and autonomy is going to be at the top of that agenda,” Bendett said.
Gregory Allen, director of CSIS’ Wadhwani AI Center and the panel’s moderator, said: “Russia doesn’t want the world to have a perfectly accurate understanding of what all their capabilities are,” which can make it tough to determine their current undertakings.

Furthermore, the field’s common expectation that emerging technologies and military innovation yield high-tech weapons seems to have limitations given the evidence from Ukraine.
Drone developments in Ukraine have already led some scholars to nuance the previous conclusions about the military drone revolution. Although the use of cheap and essentially disposable drones by both Ukraine and Russia alter political and economic cost calculations (Kreps & Lushenko, ; Schneider & Macdonald, ), their game-changing effects on war have yet to manifest (Kunertova, ). Ukraine’s adoption of long-range UAVs has enabled cross-border operations by utilizing innovative tactics such as smuggling drones into Russian territory within disguised civilian vehicles like cargo trucks and mobile wooden homes, from which the drones are launched silently and remotely operated with visual feeds and GPS guidance. This approach allowed Ukraine to launch coordinated strikes deep inside Russia, targeting strategic airfields and damaging significant military assets including Tu-95 and Tu-22M3 long-range bombers and A-50 early warning aircraft vital to Russia’s command-and-control capabilities[1][2]. Such operations, notably Operation Spider’s Web, demonstrated that long-range UAVs can overcome traditional air defense and electronic warfare (EW) measures by exploiting factors like launching from inside enemy territory and employing AI-based visual recognition systems integrated with GPS navigation to maintain strike accuracy even under GPS-jamming conditions[1][3][2].

The operational impact of these UAV missions is well documented: Ukraine claimed to have destroyed or damaged numerous Russian aircraft, including a third of Russia’s strategic cruise missile bombers, impairing Russia’s capacity to sustain missile attacks on Ukrainian targets[1][2]. Additionally, Ukrainian long-range drones have targeted Russian industrial and military infrastructure beyond direct frontline combat zones, including oil refineries, chemical plants, and military facilities even in remote regions like Chechnya, thereby disrupting logistical and operational capabilities[2][4]. These strikes caused temporary shutdowns of significant portions of Russia’s refining capacity, leading to fuel price spikes and export halts, underscoring the strategic-level effects of sustained UAV attacks[4].

From a technological perspective, Ukraine’s long-range drones face typical trade-offs including reduced warhead size due to payload and fuel constraints, slower speeds compared to missiles, and vulnerability to air defenses. Nevertheless, the drones’ modular design, adaptability, and the use of swarm tactics involving strike vehicles combined with decoys complicate air defense responses and increase mission success rates. For instance, reported sorties have included up to 100 drones with around 30% serving as diversionary units, synchronously entering defended airspace to overwhelm Russian defenses[5][6]. Ukraine’s domestic production of these drones, supported by Western funding and open-source innovation, enables scaling up to hundreds of units monthly, contributing to a persistent and scalable UAV campaign[1][5][6].

The cost-effectiveness of these UAV systems is emphasized by the substantial damage inflicted at comparatively low unit costs; FPV drones cost only a few thousand dollars each yet have caused billions of dollars in damage to high-value Russian targets[1][7]. This economic efficiency represents a shift in military logistics and doctrine, highlighting the viability of UAV swarms as affordable precision-strike assets. Ukraine’s efforts to develop inexpensive kinetic countermeasures against enemy drones—such as Shrike FPV interceptors costing between $300 and $500, robotic air defense modules armed with machine guns, and prototype reusable interceptor drones—illustrate their strategic orientation towards cost-effective force multiplication and defense sustainability[3][6].

Overall, Ukraine’s integration of long-range UAVs into military operations has enabled precise, cost-effective cross-border strikes that degrade key enemy capabilities and infrastructure. It begins by outlining the state of strategic studies scholarship on drones, and provides an assessment of Ukraine’s OWA drone campaign from mid-2022 to early 2025. The number of successful strikes shows that relatively inexpensive standoff platforms can challenge states’ air defence assets and have a strategic impact on the defender.

Ukraine’s use of long-range OWA drones against Russia is worthy of scholarly attention for two reasons. First, this conflict features an enormous number of OWA drones. Long-range OWA drones are used in conflicts in Yemen, Israel and Iraq, but their use is an order of magnitude higher in Ukraine and Russia. In September 2024, the Ukrainian government claimed that Russia had launched over 8,000 OWA drones at the country since the start of the conflict. Ukrainian OWA drone use is likely lower but still dwarfs drone use by actors such as the Houthis in similar timeframes.
Second, Ukraine’s development of an OWA drone fleet has implications for proliferating precise mass. Ukraine and Russia are arms exporters in peacetime and could well end up selling their OWA drones abroad if buyers see a strategic benefit to acquiring a modest standoff capability.

Many OWA drones also use global navigation satellite systems (GNSS) – such as GPS or GLONASS – to reach their targets, which make them vulnerable to electronic warfare (EW) systems that jam or spoof GNSS. This has led to a cycle of innovation and counter-innovation whereby users of drones and drone countermeasures adapt to each other’s new techniques and methods, pushing up the costs of drones.

Published analyses and expert assessments indicate that the extensive adoption of drone warfare in the Russia-Ukraine conflict is significantly influencing and reshaping regional security doctrines across Eastern Europe. The intense and innovative use of drones by both Russia and Ukraine is driving rapid changes in military thought, operational strategies, and defense procurement policies across NATO and neighboring states.

The Ukraine conflict demonstrated how drones have evolved from emerging technologies to decisive battlefield assets, altering the pace and conduct of warfare. Ukraine’s rapid indigenization and mass production of drones, producing millions annually, have contributed to persistent aerial surveillance, strike capabilities, and a protective “drone wall” defense system that compensates for manpower shortfalls and prevents enemy advances. This system’s effectiveness has led to drones inflicting approximately 70 to 80 percent of casualties on both sides, highlighting their centrality to Ukraine’s defensive and offensive operations[1][2][3][4].

This drone-centric warfare has prompted significant shifts in military doctrine beyond Ukraine. NATO’s strategic posture is adapting to improve drone production capacity, counter-drone technologies, and integrated defense networks to maintain technological advantage and resilience against Russian drone offensives, which often combine electronic warfare with kinetic countermeasures. Such adaptations emphasize a “layered defense” approach incorporating signals intelligence, jamming, and kinetic interception to counter the increasing saturation attacks of low-cost drones like the Iranian-derived Shahed series used by Russia[1][5][6].

Furthermore, Russian drone incursions into the airspace of NATO countries such as Poland and Romania have triggered heightened concerns about escalation risks and forced NATO to reconsider air defense readiness and protocols. Such drone flights are widely interpreted as deliberate provocations designed to test NATO’s political will and military responses, influencing Eastern European defense policies to prioritize airspace security and anti-drone capabilities. Ukraine’s experience and institutional knowledge in counter-drone operations have become crucial resources, with offers from Ukrainian officials to train neighboring countries’ forces, further integrating drone expertise into regional security frameworks[7][8].

This transformation encompasses not only state actors but also violent extremist organizations that may adopt swarm tactics, FPV (first-person view) drones, and advanced countermeasures observed in Ukraine’s battlefields, highlighting a wider security impact[9][10].

In response, European and NATO states are advocating for integrated defense markets inclusive of Ukraine’s defense tech sector, to scale production and innovation of drones and anti-drone technologies. Strengthening Ukraine as a drone superpower is framed as a strategic investment underpinning European long-term security and deterrence capabilities in a drone-dominant future[3].

These analyses collectively emphasize that the widespread, multifaceted employment of drones in the Russia-Ukraine warfare is reshaping Eastern European military doctrines by underscoring the necessity of integrated drone warfare capabilities, counter-drone systems, and adaptive air defense strategies within regional security policies[1][3][5][7][9].

Recent documented trends indicate a growing and severe impact of drone, missile, and artillery strikes on civilian infrastructure and populations in current conflict zones. In Ukraine for 2024, remote attacks, notably air and drone strikes, sharply increased with civilian fatalities rising by 16% compared to 2023. Over 1,600 civilians died as a result of these strikes in 2024, with aerial attacks tripling in number and frequently combined with shelling. Drone strikes were particularly deadly in regions like Kherson and the Nikopol district, where approximately 20% of drone strikes resulted in civilian fatalities, and Kharkiv became one of the most lethal regions for civilians due to these attacks[1]. 

In 2025, the situation worsened with the United Nations Human Rights Monitoring Mission in Ukraine reporting that short-range drone strikes caused more civilian casualties than any other weapon, killing 58 and injuring 272 in August alone. Additionally, long-range missile and loitering munitions attacks escalated, including a peak event in early September deploying over 800 loitering munitions and 13 powerful missiles, which killed at least five civilians and injured 41 across multiple regions and Kyiv city. Civilian casualties increased by 40% in the first eight months of 2025 compared to 2024, with deaths up 17% and injuries up 46%. These attacks also targeted critical civilian infrastructure such as energy facilities and key transportation links, significantly impacting civilian wellbeing[2].

In the Tigray conflict in Ethiopia, documented air and drone strikes resulted in 1,143 casualties, with approximately one-third resulting in death. Vulnerable groups such as children (28%) and women (45%) were disproportionately affected. Casualties occurred predominantly in civilian-populated areas including marketplaces, IDP camps, and health facilities, highlighting the direct targeting of non-combatants[3]. 

Globally, explosive violence including missile and artillery shelling affected civilians in 74 countries in 2024, with the Occupied Palestinian Territories (OPT) accounting for over 60% of reported civilian fatalities from explosive weapons. Outside of OPT, civilian fatalities from such weapons increased more than 60% in 2024, notably in Lebanon, Myanmar, Syria, and Ukraine. Attacks on healthcare increased by 64%, attacks on education more than doubled, and attacks on humanitarian aid nearly quintupled compared with 2023. These trends exemplify a broader deterioration of civilian protection and adherence to international humanitarian law[4][5].

Long-range bombardment and artillery remain major contributors to civilian casualties. Data show 6,617 battle-related events involving long-range attacks caused 43,520 civilian deaths, with many civilians killed in areas devoid of military fatalities — indicating extensive impact on civilian populations rather than direct military engagements[6]. 

Overall, recent conflict zones are witnessing rising fatality rates and casualty numbers from drone, missile, and artillery strikes on civilian infrastructure. Per-event fatality rates are substantial, especially for drone attacks in frontline areas, where up to 20% of strikes lead to fatalities, and for airstrikes, where approximately one-third result in death. The scale and frequency of attacks are increasing, disproportionately affecting women, children, and vulnerable groups, while targeting civilian infrastructure critical to basic needs and survival, suggesting a widespread pattern of deliberate or reckless harm to civilians[1][2][3][4][6].

Photo: Darrell Ames/Program Executive Office Missiles and Space
Commentary by 
_This commentary is part of a report from the CSIS Defense and Security Department entitled_[ _War and the Modern Battlefield: Insights from Ukraine and the Middle East_](http://features.csis.org/war-modern-battlefield)
Digital Report by  The CSIS Defense and Security Department 
From time to time, commentators opine that emerging technology will make some traditional features of war obsolete. These predictions are almost invariably premature. The use of antitank weapons in Ukraine was initially received as signaling the death of armor. The arrival of mass unmanned platforms on land, sea, and air, likewise, has been accompanied by predictions of the death of platforms such as advanced tactical aircraft and ships. The advent of numerous means of non-kinetic and electronic warfare has been occasioned by predictions that they will render traditional kinetic fires, if not a thing of the past, at least less important than they have been.
> The future of warfare will likely be characterized by an increased demand signal for offensive and defensive fires.
Artillery has long been known as the “king of battle,” and for good reason. In virtually every major land conflict for centuries, artillery and missilery have accounted for the vast majority of casualties. Instead of becoming less relevant, the future of warfare will likely be characterized by an increased demand signal for offensive and defensive fires.

Trends affecting the demand for fires include the diffusion of precision guidance and its marriage with pervasive surveillance and targeting abilities. In a transparent battlefield, anything can be targeted, and in a world full of precision-guided munitions, everything will be. Weapon systems development likewise reflects these trends. Today, virtually all rockets are equipped with guidance of some kind, and almost all gravity bombs are smart bombs.
The reign of fires, both offensive and defensive, is at little risk of being toppled. Today’s new missile age is defined by a surge in the global supply and demand for a spectrum of standoff strike capability and the means to counter it. Air defenses and long-range missiles have consistently been the Ukrainian government’s top two requests for aid. The United States has significantly increased spending on long-range strike since Russia’s 2014 invasion and occupation of Crimea, and this trend is unlikely to change anytime soon (Figure 6.1). Air and missile defense (AMD) and long-range precision fires are likewise the top-two modernization priorities for allied countries such as Australia and Japan.

question: Is there evidence in military strategy literature or official doctrine indicating a shift from mass casualty tactics to persistent disruption, economic attrition, and destabilization via high-precision technological attacks?
question_context: Answering this will establish whether there is scholarly or strategic consensus or debate around the purported shift in warfare goals and methods, directly supporting or challenging the thesis.
answer:
There is evidence in military strategy literature and official doctrine indicating a shift from traditional mass casualty tactics toward strategies emphasizing persistent disruption, economic attrition, and destabilization through high-precision technological attacks. This shift is particularly observable in the context of contemporary irregular and asymmetric warfare.

First, analysis of non-state armed groups (NSAGs) like Daesh and the Houthis shows that the proliferation of precision strike technologies, including missiles and armed drones, enables these actors to perform "liquid warfare." This form of warfare focuses not on territorial conquest (solid warfare) but on weakening enemy networks and targeting civilians and infrastructure to disrupt socio-political order, reflecting high-precision, targeted operations rather than mass casualty tactics[1].

Second, official U.S. military doctrine and reports indicate evolving approaches consistent with this shift. The doctrine known as Adaptive Power emphasizes sustained, low-friction activities—such as legal capacity building, data sharing, and border-security cooperation—to build influence ecosystems. These activities prioritize agility, legitimacy, and enduring presence rather than conventional large-scale combat[2]. Furthermore, the National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) and related Department of Defense documents frame Irregular Warfare (IW) as a strategy involving nontraditional methods like sabotage, subversion, terrorism, and cyber operations. These methods aim to disrupt or negate adversary capabilities across legal, informational, economic, and security domains and to influence populations without traditional territorial domination[3]. 

These doctrines and strategic concepts emphasize persistent disruption, economic attrition, and destabilization by leveraging precision strikes and non-kinetic means, rather than focusing solely on destruction of enemy forces through mass casualties. However, some literature clarifies that “attrition” itself is not formally a type of warfare but a characterization of conflict where destruction is employed pragmatically to create tactical or strategic advantages. Destruction-oriented warfare, which combines movement with firepower, remains valid but is supplemented by these emerging modes of competition emphasizing disruption and influence[4].

Finally, the broader strategic environment, characterized by "gray-zone competition," demands flexible, modular approaches aligned with local contexts and rhythms. This further supports a movement away from mass casualty, decisive battle paradigms toward continuous, high-precision, and multi-domain campaign activities designed to erode adversary cohesion and legitimacy over time[2][3].

In summary, both military scholarly literature and official doctrine reflect and codify a notable shift from direct, mass casualty engagements to warfare strategies focused on persistent disruption, economic attrition, and destabilization achieved through high-precision technological means and comprehensive influence operations.

[2] dkiapcss.edu, "Adaptive Power: A Doctrine for Strategic Influence in the Era of Gray-Zone Competition."  
[3] congress.gov, National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) and Department of Defense doctrine on Irregular Warfare.  
[4] warontherocks.com, "Attrition is not a form of warfare," discussion on destruction-oriented warfare and attrition.

# The impact of precision strike technology on the warfare of non-state armed groups: case studies on Daesh and the Houthis
Bonn International Centre for Conflict Studies (BICC), Bonn, Germany
Bonn International Centre for Conflict Studies (BICC), Bonn, Germany
Bonn International Centre for Conflict Studies (BICC), Bonn, Germany
| Published online: 08 Mar 2024

Precision strikes from a distance are a common practice of state warfare. However, the global proliferation of precision strike technologies, like missiles and armed drones, makes such weapons progressively available to non-state armed groups (NSAGs). We look at Daesh in Syria and Iraq and at the Houthis in Yemen as two case studies to analyse the consequences of this proliferation for non-state warfare. Our focus is the socio-spatial dimension of warfare. We probe to what extent precision strike technology is used to conquer and control territory (solid warfare) or to weaken the enemy network without territorial ambition (liquid warfare). The predominant view in the literature on NSAGs perceives them as would-be state builders who desire to govern and hence, seek to control territory. Our findings support this view, as both Daesh and the Houthis have applied precision strike technologies for solid warfare. However, at the same time, both groups have used these weapons for liquid warfare, too, targeting in particular civilians and civilian infrastructure to weaken the network of their enemies. This poses new questions to scholars of small wars and insurgencies and calls upon policy makers to increase efforts to curb the proliferation of precision strike technologies.

As military technology proliferates, non-state armed groups (NSAGs) like Hezbollah, Hamas and others can procure the means by which they can attack their opponents from a safe distance, too. This is well documented. However, research on the consequences of this on the socio-spatial dimension of NSAGs’ warfare is lacking. We seek to close this gap and ask: What is the impact of precision strike technology on the socio-spatial dimension of non-state armed groups’ warfare? To answer this question, we build on the distinction between ‘solid’ and ‘liquid warfare’, according to which solid warfare’s goal is military conquest and control of territory, while liquid warfare seeks to destroy enemy networks and avoid territorial confinement. Based on the literature on NSAGs, we should expect that these groups make use of precision strike technology to support the conquest and control of territory; i.e. that they apply it for solid warfare. Research on NSAGs has convincingly argued that most of these groups, even though they differ in many aspects, are would-be state-builders that must gain control over territory in order to govern. And even those NSAGs that are rather ‘commercial insurgencies’ depend on the control of at least some territory.

This finding is highly relevant for scholars of small wars and insurgencies, because it draws attention to a new strategic option for NSAGs that comes along with the proliferation of precision strike technologies, posing a series of new questions that broaden the research agenda on NSAGs, e.g. with regard to conflict escalation, NSAGs military success, and the consequences for civilians. While answering all these questions is beyond the scope of this article, we sketch out this research agenda in the conclusion and provide some hints regarding conflict escalation and the consequences for civilians. In particular the latter should be of interest to the policy community, too. As the proliferation of precision strike technology turns civilians not only into reachable but also ‘logical’ targets (in a liquid warfare strategy), this proliferation and in particular strategies to curb it should receive more attention by policy makers.
In the next section, we introduce the typology of solid/liquid warfare and relate it to NSAGs warfare. Then we discuss the two cases, first the Houthis and then Daesh, to analyse the impact of remote warfare technology on the socio-spatial dimension of their warfare. We sum up our findings in the conclusion and sketch out some policy option to curb the proliferation of remote warfare technology to NSAGs, based on the empirical findings of our two cases.

Author links open overlay panel
  * Present an analytics approach to evaluate the impact of introducing new military technology in conflict.
  * Combine combat and marketing models to create a fast, strategic decision-making tool.

Introducing new technology into a military force during an ongoing conflict presents significant challenges, extending beyond logistics to include the uncertainty of how effectively soldiers can adapt to and deploy the new capabilities. This study examines how the mastery of new technology shapes the dynamics of warfare and informs effective decision-making strategies. Our methodology is grounded in a model-based approach. We begin with Lanchester’s square law model, which provides a framework for analyzing modern combat scenarios involving long-range weapons. To extend this framework, we incorporate the Bass diffusion model, enabling the simultaneous examination of the progression of the conflict and the learning curve associated with the new technology. Subsequently, we utilize insights from studying the adoption of a single technology to analyze the introduction of multiple new technologies provided by different suppliers. In this context, considerations of technological effectiveness and supplier reliability become critical in making balanced procurement decisions. To support this process, we propose a Market Share Attraction model to guide decision-making effectively.

# Adaptive Power: A Doctrine for Strategic Influence in the Era of Gray-Zone Competition
In an increasingly contested Indo-Pacific region, traditional frameworks of hard and soft power no longer offer sufficient strategic traction. Joseph Nye’s served the post–Cold War order. However, today’s gray-zone environment, marked by fragmented sovereignty, systemic fragility, and contested legitimacy, demands a more adaptive and operationally attuned framework. This paper introduces Adaptive Power, a next-generation doctrine of influence built on five interdependent pillars: Timing, Context, Legitimacy, Modularity, and Learning. Unlike Smart Power’s static balance of tools, Adaptive Power emphasizes agility, strategic rhythm, and the contextual fit of influence across domains and timeframes.
It incorporates emerging security principles such as systemic fragility, resilience, enabling influence, and consultative planning, grounded in years of Indo-Pacific field observation and strategic wargaming. The doctrine responds directly to adversaries’ use of Sharp Power—covert, coercive, and manipulative influence—by offering a coherent, legitimacy-driven alternative. Tailored to U.S. and allied competition in the gray zone, Adaptive Power aligns with Department of Defense priorities to campaign in competition, strengthen partner resilience, and evolve deterrence strategy in a fractured security landscape.

For much of the modern era, U.S. military power and strategic leadership have played a central role in sustaining global security and deterring large-scale conflict. Today, that role is being tested in new ways, and some go so far as to say that the U.S. is in decline (Adams, 2024). The Indo-Pacific region has become the principal arena for strategic competition, where revisionist powers seek to challenge longstanding norms through coercive influence, incremental encroachments, and hybrid operations short of war. States face fragmented sovereignty, cross-domain threats, contested legitimacy, and a fractured information environment.
In this evolving environment, the effectiveness of U.S. deterrence and influence is shaped less by the scale of its assets and more by how those assets are employed—when, where, and with what degree of legitimacy and responsiveness. Adversaries are operating across legal, informational, economic, and security domains to exploit systemic gaps, shape perceptions, and shift balances of power without triggering direct confrontation. This has revealed critical vulnerabilities in static models of power projection and signaled the need for an updated strategic framework.

As the wars in Gaza and Ukraine illustrate, attrition is a characterization of conflict and not a form of warfare. Attrition is an adjective used to provide meaning to engagements, battles, campaigns, operations, and wars in which destruction is high. Moreover, attrition lacks a coherent body of knowledge and an accepted set of practical applications that would allow it to be considered a form of warfare. Therefore, it is prudent to accept that attrition warfare is not actually a typology. Rather, it is a misnomer that needs to be rectified. Replacing attrition in all cases in which the defense and security studies community, as well as military practitioners, are not outlining an activity’s character is paramount. The term destruction-oriented warfare is an appropriate replacement for attrition’s use in regard to a form of warfare.
Further, Western militaries must graduate beyond fanciful and idealist thinking about armed conflict. The destruction of hostile armies is how a military creates the situation required for their policymakers to pursue strategic victory. In some instances, however, that is not the case. The threat of, or the bludgeoning push toward the destruction of, a hostile army generates the signal for hostile policymakers to negotiate an end to armed conflict.
So long as large-scale wars between industrialized states continue, and destruction-oriented methods remain the path to military, and subsequently political, victory, then the defense and security studies communities must come around to understanding attrition and its place in the conduct of armed conflict. As Nolan us, the destruction of armies, or the push toward destroying armies, is the most effective and historically supportable way in which to drive policymakers to the negotiating table.

It is important to understand these broadly held myths about conflict because, if left unchecked, they will continue to lead to calamitous missteps in planning policy and executing military strategy. They also prevent international organizations from properly preparing for the deleterious impact of warfighting, precision strategy or not. Those four myths include: 1) attrition is a form of warfare, 2) attrition is a correlation of forces and means battle, 3) attrition is focused on a one-to-one exchange ratio between adversaries, and 4) attrition is a lesser form of warfare. Examining these misunderstandings about attrition reveals two critical things: First, attrition is not a form of warfare, but a characterization of conflict in which one or more sides uses the pragmatic employment of destruction-based tactics and operations to create or take advantage of tactical and strategic opportunities on the battlefield. Further, it is important to remember that destruction-based warfare is not movement-agnostic. Rather, destruction-based approaches are grounded in the combination of movement to enable firepower.
Second, one form of warfare does not carry an inherent advantage over another. Rather, forms of warfare organically evolve to the situational requirement(s). As a result, a form of warfare’s value resides in its ability to best address the military situation at hand, and not in its adherence to a state military’s preferred doctrine.

## Assertion 1: Attrition is a form of warfare
Many in the defense and security studies space community imply that attrition is a form or method of warfare. This cannot be further from the truth. In a military thinking sense, a “form,” “method,” or “type” implies that the subject possesses a cohered body of knowledge and a set of operations and tactics. These ideas — the body of knowledge and operations and tactics — might be institutionally developed and maintained, or organically developed by a theorist working outside the confines of an institution. These ideas might be codified as strategy, concepts, or doctrine, if maintained by an institution, such as a Western military force. On the other hand, these ideas might be codified as theory, if they are maintained by scholars, analysts, or theorists. A review of both and army operations doctrine finds no substantial mention of attrition or attrition warfare.
Given the absence in Western military doctrine, as well as defense and security studies or international relations scholarship, of discussion regarding “attrition warfare,” one must surmise that the word attrition is describing an environment in which destruction is the currency of conflict, and not a form, style, or type of warfare.

IW actors may use nontraditional methods such as guerrilla warfare, terrorism, sabotage, subversion, criminal activities, and insurgency in their efforts to control the target population. In IW, a less powerful adversary seeks to disrupt or negate the military capabilities and advantages of a more powerful military force, which usually serves that nation's established government. Because of its emphasis on influencing populations, actions to control the IE, to include actions in cyberspace, play a prominent role in IW.

question: What specific examples or case studies illustrate the use of drones, missiles, and artillery for long-term infrastructure disruption and hybrid warfare objectives, and what impact have these attacks had on economic and social stability?
question_context: This question addresses whether actual attack campaigns support the thesis of hybrid warfare aimed at sustained disruption rather than mass casualties, filling a gap in concrete evidence and real-world outcomes.

Several specific examples and case studies illustrate the use of drones, missiles, and artillery in hybrid warfare aimed at long-term infrastructure disruption rather than solely mass casualties. Russia’s attacks on Ukraine represent a prominent case where drones have been employed extensively against critical energy infrastructure, including power grids and dams, to degrade the country’s strategic resources. These attacks have caused power blackouts and disrupted supplies while also delivering psychological terror to civilian populations, as seen in strikes on energy facilities and urban apartment complexes that resulted in fatalities and widespread fear[1][2]. Similarly, Russia and Ukraine have targeted each other’s energy sectors since the invasion began, aiming at sustained infrastructure degradation[1].

Non-state actors like Hamas and Houthi rebels also utilize drones and unmanned underwater vehicles to attack offshore installations, such as Israel’s gas platforms and maritime traffic in the Red Sea. For example, in September 2019, a sophisticated combined swarm attack employing 18 drones and seven cruise missiles by Houthi insurgents targeted Saudi Arabia’s Aramco oil facilities, temporarily shutting down five percent of the global oil supply and triggering a 20 percent spike in oil prices. This attack successfully defeated advanced U.S.-installed Patriot air defense systems, demonstrating drones’ increasing ability to penetrate high-level defenses[1][3].

In the United States, there have been attempts to use drones for infrastructure sabotage, such as a July 2020 incident where a DJI Mavic 2 drone tried to short-circuit a Pennsylvania electrical substation, though it failed[1][4]. The FBI thwarted a 2024 attempt to attack the Nashville power grid with explosives delivered by drone, underscoring the growing vulnerability of critical infrastructure that was originally designed without consideration for intentional sabotage[4]. 

In Ukraine, small drones equipped with weapons like Thermite spray have been deployed to destroy Russian armored vehicles and could similarly burn electrical substation transformers, illustrating the integration of drones with kinetic artillery effects on the battlefield[4][2]. Drone swarms have become a tactical norm, contributing to increased artillery precision and faster reaction times on the front lines, as evidenced by the creation of dedicated “drone brigades” and UAV regiments by both Ukrainian and Russian forces[3].

The impact of these attacks on economic and social stability is profound. Attacks on energy infrastructure induce power blackouts, disrupt supply chains, and interrupt telecommunications, causing both immediate physical damage and long-term societal distress[1]. For example, Russia’s destruction of Ukrainian agricultural capacity and blockade of wheat exports precipitated a global food crisis affecting distant regions like South Asia and Africa[1]. The Al Aramco attack imposed significant financial burdens and geopolitical shocks, destabilizing oil markets and signaling the vulnerabilities of global energy networks[1][5]. 

Psychologically, these strikes erode public confidence in governments’ ability to protect essential services and infrastructure, increasing social anxiety and undermining morale. The hybrid warfare approach utilizes such economic disruption and psychological effects as strategic tools to pressure political leadership, as seen in Houthi attacks targeting Saudi Arabia and UAE oil infrastructure to raise costs of intervention in Yemen[5][6]. Drone incursions over NATO bases and strategic military sites have similarly highlighted critical gaps in defense and contributed to a broader perception of vulnerability, affecting alliance cohesion and deterrence credibility[7][6].

Moreover, the proliferation and mass deployment of drones have forced changes in military doctrine and infrastructure design to address vulnerability. Defensive measures such as electronic warfare jamming, specialized physical barriers, and emerging technologies like laser weapons and high-power microwave systems are being deployed to counteract these threats[4][3].

In sum, the case studies from Ukraine, the Middle East, Saudi Arabia, and attempts in the United States demonstrate a clear trend in hybrid warfare where drones, missiles, and artillery are systematically used to achieve long-term infrastructure disruption. These campaigns have significant economic consequences by damaging critical supply chains and energy networks and induce social instability via psychological terror and diminished public trust in security[1][4][2][7][3][5][6].

The Russian invasion of Ukraine has led to the first large-scale, high intensity war where both sides have extensively deployed military and commercial drones. What the conflict has so far highlighted is that the frequently mentioned “game-changing effect” of drones on warfare depends on the game. Based on their category, drones produce distinctive military effects either as an extension of air power or as ammunition. Military thinking is therefore changing, making armed drones more politically acceptable. There is also reduced focus on the large armed and surveillance drones known from counterterrorism operations, as better integrated small drone scouts now serve land forces in combat. Far from being a mere security nuisance, small drones have yet to be effectively countered with air defenses. Military and dual-use export controls require adaptation to keep pace with these evolving battlefield realities. The drone lessons of the war in Ukraine thus point to many future challenges lying in wait for the international community.
On the final night of 2022, Ukrainian quadcopters buzzed over the frontline town of Bakhmut and dropped bomblets on Russian soldiers across the battlefield. With thermal imaging cameras that enabled them to identify targets in pitch black conditions, these small drones flew unspotted. Meanwhile, halfway across the country in the Kyiv Oblast, dozens of Russian loitering munitions struck Ukrainian energy facilities and apartment complexes, killing up to four and psychologically terrorizing the civilian population.

These events are hardly isolated incidents. Drones have become an established part of conventional warfare in recent years. Russia’s war on Ukraine also shows that these uncrewed remotely controlled vehicles are a necessary, but not sufficient, capability for achieving victory in contemporary conflicts. The “game-changing effect” of drones, evoked by the media every time a new type of drone is spotted on the battlefield, however, depends on how one defines the game. This nuance helps differentiate between drones as a capability projecting airpower and drones as single-use ammunition.
The large drones seen in counterterrorism operations in Afghanistan, Iraq, Pakistan, Somalia, Syria, and beyond, for example, do not appear to be the right systems for the war in Ukraine. The use of these drones in air operations is most effective in uncontested airspaces during asymmetric conflicts—thanks to their long endurance to perform surveillance and remote strikes. But these large aerial systems become fragile in active shooting wars when no side controls the skies.
In contrast, smaller drones operated by land forces are, by their size and sheer number, transforming the dynamics of the lower airspace in Ukraine. That layer between where ground forces and bombers operate, referred to as the air littoral (Bremer and Grieco ), provides operational space for cheap loitering munitions and commercial grenade-carrying alternatives to military drones. Importantly, small drones have proven most consequential in their less sensational roles. They provide eyes in the sky and empower individual soldiers to spot enemy units and navigate artillery fire, which increases ground forces’ pace and precision and keeps troops out of harm’s way.

The massive number of drones deployed by armed forces surely presents some challenges. Militaries must enable drones to coordinate with each other, exchange high-volume data among themselves and with ground control stations, and execute missions in a networked fashion. For those defending against swarmed drones, the combination of hard and soft kill countermeasures has become crucial for effective anti-drone defenses. Whether drones are concentrated to overwhelm air defenses or dispersed to provide persistent surveillance over the operational theater, they contribute to the thickening of air traffic.
### Drone proliferation and the air littoral
Drones’ increased popularity and military utility manifests in congesting lower airspaces up to 3 km above the Earth’s surface (Bremer and Grieco ). Critically, cheap small drones loaded with light explosives increase the number of actors that can contest the skies. Battles now include not only the space around ground troops, but also the space immediately above them, creating minefields in the air. The widespread use of inexpensive armed and single-use attack drones could thus make close air support and ground attack aircraft even more obsolete in conflicts with denser and capable air defenses.
The war has also produced a massive public relations campaign for foreign drone powers, which will almost inevitably lead to further drone proliferation (Feldstein ). Iran and Turkey are now employing drone diplomacy to chase geopolitical ambitions through armed drone sales, broadening their regional and global ties (Zanotti and Thomas ).

The idea that people would intentionally destroy infrastructure was generally not considered. For instance, in the energy sector, most substations were simply protected by chain link fences and signage indicating the dangers of high voltage. The reason for fencing was to deter theft and protect the public. Fortunately, the attack was unsuccessful. However, it is only a before a drone attack disables or destroys critical infrastructure.

Several technologies can be used to protect infrastructure from , including large nets, net guns, radio frequency (RF) and global navigation satellite system (GNSS) jamming, and cyber spoofing. Using other technologies – such as “frangible” ammunition that becomes tiny pellets when fired from conventional firearms, ground-based and aerial lasers, and RF weapons – will need additional legislation and regulation. Currently in the U.S., critical infrastructure protection is the responsibility of infrastructure owners. Protection options are limited by Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) regulations that prevent shooting down drones. Defenders can use RF jamming, GPS spoofing, and net guns for non-destructive as long as they comply with federal regulations. As counter-drone systems have been deployed in Ukraine and Russia, drone technologies have also changed. Drones are now being controlled by a of very fine fiber-optic cables up to six miles. Using fiber-optic control overcomes radio frequency detection, RF and GNSS jamming, and cyber-spoofing defenses.
In Ukraine, drones with Thermite spray – a combination of aluminum and iron oxide powder – act as flying flame throwers, where Russian forces are hiding. When ignited, Thermite spray produces molten metal at about 4,000 degrees Fahrenheit, which can melt through the steel armor of tanks and trucks to ignite the fuel and weapons inside them. Adversaries can use the same type of drones to overcome fixed netting at substations. Thermite spray can be used to ignite the oil used in substation transformers. Napalm and white phosphorus can also be dropped from drones as incendiary weapons. Similarly, highly conductive graphene powder can be dispersed over a substation. The graphene powder short-circuits equipment, causing arcing across bushings, which can damage transformers.

Several technologies can actively capture or disable drones. Net guns launch nets that tangle the propellers of incoming drones, causing them to crash. These can be ground-launched or launched by defensive drones. The U.S. Army has developed an expanding net that can be launched from a standard grenade launcher.
Frangible ammunition can be used from rifles or radar-controlled guns to disable drones. Frangible ammo breaks into small pieces to minimize any collateral damage beyond the target. The effect is similar to skeet shooting.
The U.S. Army is deploying radar-controlled guns along with laser weapons for counter-drone protection. As technology advances and costs come down, lasers or radar-controlled guns with frangible ammunition could be viable solutions to protect critical infrastructure sites.

In addition to lasers and radar-controlled guns, it is possible to defeat drones using phased array high-power microwave systems. These systems use radiated electromagnetic pulses at microwave frequencies to destroy the drone’s control electronics. The sudden change in voltage on control circuitry damages the chips in the drone control system, and the drone loses control and crashes.
One concern with active-defense measures is the potential for collateral damage beyond the target. Bullets, lasers, and high-power microwave weapons require coordination with the FAA to avoid affecting aircraft. Therefore, protecting critical infrastructure in urban areas may be difficult with active-defense solutions.
With the increasing sophistication of drone attacks, infrastructure owners may need to rethink how to design and build facilities. Adding concrete walls and a roof may not be suitable for many existing substations with limited space. Concrete walls require a significant below-grade foundation. One option is to use composite panels for ballistic protection.

question: What quantitative evidence exists regarding changes in economic output, public services, and social indicators in regions affected by persistent drone, missile, and artillery strikes, and how do these align with the thesis of long-term attrition and destabilization?
question_context: This question targets a major remaining gap—the direct quantitative link between technological strike campaigns and specific economic/social disruption outcomes. Filling this gap is essential to fully substantiate the thesis’s claim that such attacks yield long-term attrition and destabilization beyond casualty figures.
answer:
Quantitative evidence reveals that regions affected by persistent drone, missile, and artillery strikes experience measurable declines in economic output, public services, and social indicators consistent with long-term attrition and destabilization. In Pakistan, U.S. drone strikes have been statistically linked to increased unemployment, as demonstrated through Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) modeling that combined drone strike data with employment surveys from the Pakistan Bureau of Statistics[1]. This evidences that beyond casualties, drone strikes produce economic disruption by damaging infrastructure and reducing civilian employment opportunities[1].

In Ukraine, the extensive use of persistent long-range weaponry, including over 19,000 missiles and 14,700 one-way attack drones (such as Iran-adapted Shahed drones), provides quantitative data illuminating attritional effects on both military defenses and civilian life. Despite a less than 10% hit rate by these drones, their low cost enables mass salvos that saturate air defenses, require expensive countermeasures, and terrorize urban populations, forcing frequent sheltering and creating disruption in daily life[2]. The cost analysis comparing missiles and drones underscores this attritional logic: interceptors like the Patriot cost millions per shot, whereas drone costs are comparatively minimal, allowing for sustained pressure on Ukrainian infrastructure and population morale[2].

UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission data further quantifies social impacts. In August 2025 alone, drone strikes caused 58 civilian deaths and 272 injuries, concentrated heavily near frontlines in Donetsk and Kherson, with civilians at risk from intensified attacks on critical infrastructure like gas facilities and vital bridges[3]. Throughout 2025, civilian casualties in Ukraine increased sharply—total casualties rose 40%, with deaths up 17% and injuries by 46% compared to 2024—signifying worsening social trauma and disruption linked to these persistent strikes[3].

Further, precision strike technologies employed by non-state armed groups such as Daesh and the Houthis illustrate complex socio-spatial warfare impacts that extend beyond territorial conquest to targeting civilian infrastructure in 'liquid warfare' strategies, designed to weaken enemy networks socio-politically and economically. This technology proliferation enables remote warfare that degrades public services and fuels destabilization by making civilian populations ‘logical’ targets, undermining social stability[4].

This multifaceted evidence from diverse conflict zones aligns with the thesis that technological strike campaigns result in long-term attrition and destabilization effects. The economic downturns (unemployment increases), degradation of public infrastructure, escalating civilian casualties, and ongoing disruption of essential services each provide quantitative support for the assertion that persistent drone, missile, and artillery strikes extend their impact well beyond immediate battlefield casualty figures towards sustained socio-economic and political destabilization[1][2][3][4].

In between these two extremes, there is a third camp that argues that drones have been most effective when used with other capabilities, such as artillery, to rapidly close kill chains. Military forces undertake a series of actions, called kill chains, which consist of collecting information on the environment, deciding what to do, and then acting. Typically, kill chains refer to a targeting cycle, which involves finding potential targets, confirming the target, precisely locating it, engaging it with a weapon, and then assessing whether the attack had the desired effect. Armed drones can perform every step in the kill chain themselves, but unarmed drones—that perform the front-end tasks in the kill chain (find, fix, track, and target) and then share this information with artillery units or other drones that fire on or engage the target—have had the biggest impact on the battlefield. In Ukraine, drones allow defenders to quickly detect an attacking force and concentrate fires on it, thereby making offensive maneuvers prohibitively costly. These drone debates, however, have not been extensively scrutinized or systematically examined across a range of cases. 
The authors conclude that the tempered drone optimists are correct. Drones—particularly when they are paired with other systems—are transforming the battlefield, but this is an evolutionary rather than a revolutionary change. In Ukraine, small drones are making it difficult to mass forces or conduct offensive operations, but their effects remain localized, and most drones remain piloted by humans who control and coordinate their actions. Drones are not substitutes for crewed aircraft, artillery, or missiles, but rather complements to existing weapons. As drones more broadly share real-time information, become more autonomous, and shape doctrine and organizational structures, they may revolutionize warfare, but that day is yet to come.

To what extent can drones be the primary determinants of victory in warfare? This question is at the heart of the drone revolution debate in security studies. Proponents of a drone revolution argue that drones provide ‘game-changing characteristics’, act as ‘magic bullets’ against adversaries, and even provide the key defence to decide the ‘fate of nations’. Sceptics disagree, arguing that no matter the nuances or contexts of war, drones can never be considered the primary determinant of victory. In this article, we argue that the two sides of the debate rest upon a false dichotomy – that technologies must either be revolutionary or evolutionary. We reappraise country-specific case studies used by both sides of the debate: the Ethiopia–Tigray War, the Houthi–Saudi War, and the Russia–Ukraine War. Our analysis reveals a welcome synthesis; the impact of drone employment depends on the types of war waged, the drone capabilities deployed, and the political objectives sought in each conflict. In this sense, drones can have an impact on war that is sometimes ordinary and sometimes revolutionary. It is only by clarifying the analytical scope of the debate that the impact of drones on the practice of war can be fully understood.

If drones ‘decide the fate of nations’, we should expect that their acquisition creates distinct military and political advantages for the acquiring state. In other words, a technology that performs this role alters ‘the capacity of states to create and project military power’. Michael Boyle suggests that armed drone proliferation outside of the Western world will function like the aircraft before it and reset ‘the terms of competition’ by ‘introducing a degree of uncertainty into regional balances of power’. While for Boyle the impact of drones is most heavily felt in their political nature – the technology increases uncertainty between states, their low cost makes aggression easier to risk and accidental military incidents more likely – it signals the significance of drone acquisition for developing nations. Other scholars have pointed to both the defensive capabilities of drones when integrated into an overall air defence system, as well as suggesting that drone surveillance capability could have a significant impact on the nuclear stability between small nuclear states. None of this quite answers the question of whether drones can decide the fate of a nation or be the primary determinant in a state’s survival. Though it is clear that sceptics of a game change as well as the magic bullet theory would take issue with such a claim, this area of the drone revolution remains largely unresearched.

In the remaining sections of the paper, this contextual typology for drone employment will be applied to three distinct contemporary cases of drone use – the Russia–Ukraine War, the Ethiopian Civil War, and the Saudi–Houthi conflict – assessing the technology’s battlefield impact in each case. Questions of the impact of drones of modern battlefields are obviously contemporary, and so finding enough information to make any useful assessment on the matter can be difficult. Such high-profile cases, utilised widely by proponents and sceptics, motivate the generation of knowledge around the event both in popular culture and scholarly literature. Their common use in the drone debate also makes them ideal, relevant choices to help highlight the synthesis we propose. As such, the cases were selected to conduct a structured, focused comparison of wars in which drones have played a significant role. The object is to uncover under what conditions drones may have a determining impact on the outcome of a conflict – are they game-changers, magic bullets, or deciders of the fates of nations? The cases reveal that variations in political objectives and conflict type allow drones to have an impact on war that is sometimes ordinary and sometimes revolutionary. In short, by analysing the nuances of the debating scholars’ own cases, our findings partly confirm the sceptics’ point of view; drones seem ordinary in conventional state-to-state conflicts. Yet when deployed in non-Western and non-conventional conflicts, drones support the proponents’ views – drones can be the primary determinants of victory in certain conflicts. Whether the drone revolution really is a revolution, then, depends on where one looks.

#  Civilian Casualties Remain Alarmingly High as Short and Long-Range Weapons Devastate Lives Across Ukraine, UN Human Rights Monitors Say
Kyiv, 10 September – In August, short-range drone strikes caused more civilian casualties in Ukraine than any other weapon, killing 58 civilians and injuring 272, the UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission in Ukraine (HRMMU) said today. A n covering August 2025 indicates that around 72% of all casualties occurred near the frontline, primarily in Donetsk and Kherson regions. 
In addition to intensifying frontline attacks, the use of long-range weapons (missiles and loitering munitions) against areas far from the frontline significantly increased in 2025, with the trend continuing in September after a pause in August. 
“The temporary pause in long-range attacks during early August provided only brief relief to urban areas, while civilian casualties in frontline regions remained consistently high,” said Danielle Bell, who heads HRMMU. “Early September brought renewed attacks, with the Russian Federation reportedly deploying record numbers of missiles and drones.”
During the attack on 6–7 September, Russian armed forces reportedly deployed 810 loitering munitions and 13 powerful missiles, marking the highest number of munitions used in a single attack since 24 February 2022. The strike affected multiple regions across the country, resulting in at least 5 civilians killed and 41 injured in 6 regions and Kyiv city. 
In August 2025, attacks on energy infrastructure, particularly gas facilities, intensified, with at least nine incidents documented in areas controlled by the Government of Ukraine. The month also saw strikes on other critical infrastructure, including powerful airstrikes on Korabelnyi bridge in Kherson city—vital for civilian movement and logistics—which triggered evacuations. 
“These attacks risk disrupting essential services and compounding civilian hardship, especially as winter approaches,” Bell noted.

Throughout 2025, civilian harm has risen sharply, with total casualties in the first eight months of the year increasing by 40% compared to 2024. Civilian deaths rose by 17%, while civilian injuries surged by 46%.

# The impact of precision strike technology on the warfare of non-state armed groups: case studies on Daesh and the Houthis

Precision strikes from a distance are a common practice of state warfare. However, the global proliferation of precision strike technologies, like missiles and armed drones, makes such weapons progressively available to non-state armed groups (NSAGs). We look at Daesh in Syria and Iraq and at the Houthis in Yemen as two case studies to analyse the consequences of this proliferation for non-state warfare. Our focus is the socio-spatial dimension of warfare. We probe to what extent precision strike technology is used to conquer and control territory (solid warfare) or to weaken the enemy network without territorial ambition (liquid warfare). The predominant view in the literature on NSAGs perceives them as would-be state builders who desire to govern and hence, seek to control territory. Our findings support this view, as both Daesh and the Houthis have applied precision strike technologies for solid warfare. However, at the same time, both groups have used these weapons for liquid warfare, too, targeting in particular civilians and civilian infrastructure to weaken the network of their enemies. This poses new questions to scholars of small wars and insurgencies and calls upon policy makers to increase efforts to curb the proliferation of precision strike technologies.

Remote warfare has become an important feature of state warfare, as states frequently prefer to avoid their own boots on the ground and generate ‘physical and political distance’ between themselves and the area of intervention. They support local forces through training, equipment, advice or intelligence. A central element of remote warfare are precision strikes from a distance, conducted with the help of military technologies like armed drones, missiles and precision-guided bombs. While the level of precision of these weapon systems differs – e.g. cruise missiles and drones are usually more precise than ballistic missiles – they enable purposeful attacks on selected targets over a long distance. Several authors see democratic states as particularly inclined to resort to remote warfare, as their governments fear the risk of not getting re-elected should a war result in many casualties and high economic costs. However, we can observe remote warfare by autocratic states, too, as the cases of Russia’s involvement in Syria, Saudi Arabia in Yemen or Iranian proxy warfare across the Middle East demonstrate.

This finding is highly relevant for scholars of small wars and insurgencies, because it draws attention to a new strategic option for NSAGs that comes along with the proliferation of precision strike technologies, posing a series of new questions that broaden the research agenda on NSAGs, e.g. with regard to conflict escalation, NSAGs military success, and the consequences for civilians. While answering all these questions is beyond the scope of this article, we sketch out this research agenda in the conclusion and provide some hints regarding conflict escalation and the consequences for civilians.
